Chapter 10, Part 6: The Bodhisattva King of Majestic Virtue Who Illuminates Everywhere
Moreover, good sons!
How do bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who cultivate the subtle canon of the great nirvÄá¹‡a fully accomplish the ninth merit?
Good sons!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who cultivate the subtle canon of the great nirvÄá¹‡a first give rise to five things that are all accomplished.
What are the five?
First, faith; second, a sincere mind; third, precepts; fourth, being close to good friends; fifth, being very learned.
What is faith?

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas have faith in the Three Jewels, that giving has results, and have faith in the two truths, that the path of the One Vehicle has no other destination, that for the sake of sentient beings to quickly attain liberation, the buddhas and bodhisattvas distinguish it into three.
Having faith in the ultimate truth, having faith in skillful means, this is called faith.
Such faith cannot be destroyed by any Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, devas, mÄras, or BrahmÄ.
Because of this faith, one attains the nature of the holy ones.
Whether practicing generosity in abundance or in small amounts, one can all attain closeness to the great parinirvÄá¹‡a and not fall into saá¹ƒsÄra.
Precepts, learning, and wisdom are also like this.
This is called faith.
Although there is this faith, one still does not see. This is called a bodhisattva cultivating the great nirvÄá¹‡a and accomplishing the first matter.
What is called a sincere mind?
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas have a sincere mind towards all sentient beings.
All sentient beings, if they encounter conditions, then give rise to flattery and deceit, but bodhisattvas are not like this.
Why is it so?
Because they skillfully understand that all dharmas are due to conditions.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, although they see the faults and evils of sentient beings, never speak of them.
Why is it so?ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Fearing that they will give rise to afflictions, if they give rise to afflictions they will fall into evil destinies.
In this way, if a bodhisattva sees that sentient beings have even a little good, he will praise it.
What is good?
It is called buddha-nature.
By praising buddha-nature, it causes sentient beings to give rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment.
At that time, the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva Supreme Virtuous King of Universal Illumination addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!

The meaning of what the Buddha has said, that bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas praise buddha-nature and cause immeasurable sentient beings to give rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment, is not so.
Why is it so?
When the TathÄgata first opened the Nirvana Sutra, he spoke of three kinds:
First, if a sick person obtains a good doctor, medicine, and a nurse, then the illness will be easily cured, but if they do not obtain them, then it cannot be cured;
Second, whether they obtain them or not, it cannot be cured;
Third, whether they obtain it or not, they can all be cured.

All sentient beings are also like this. If they encounter good friends, buddhas, and bodhisattvas, and hear the wonderful Dharma, they will be able to give rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment. If they do not encounter [them], they will not be able to give rise to it. This refers to stream-enterers, once-returners, non-returners, arhats, and pratyekabuddhas.

Second, even if they encounter good friends, buddhas, and bodhisattvas, and hear the wonderful Dharma, they still will not be able to give rise to [the mind of enlightenment]. If they do not encounter [them], they also will not be able to give rise to it. This refers to icchantikas.
Third, whether they encounter [good friends, buddhas, and bodhisattvas] or not, they will all be able to give rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment. This refers to bodhisattvas.

If you say that whether they encounter it or not, they all give rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment, then why did the TathÄgata just now say that it is because of praising the Buddha-nature that sentient beings give rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment?
World-Honored One!

If it is the case that whether they encounter good friends, buddhas, and bodhisattvas, and hear the wonderful Dharma, or do not encounter them, they are all unable to give rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment, then this meaning is also incorrect.
Why is it so?
Because such people will attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Because those of the icchantika class, because of the Buddha-nature, whether they hear it or not, will all attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
World-Honored One!
As the Buddha has said, what are called icchantikas?
It means cutting off the roots of goodness.
This meaning is also incorrect.
Why is it so?ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Because the Buddha-nature cannot be severed.
If this is the case, then the principle of Buddha-nature cannot be severed, so why did the Buddha say that one severs all wholesome roots?
As the Buddha said in the past in the twelve divisions of the canon, wholesomeness is of two kinds:
One is permanent, the other impermanent.
The permanent cannot be severed, the impermanent can be severed.
Because the impermanent can be severed, one falls into hell.
Why is the permanent, which cannot be severed, not blocked? The Buddha-nature cannot be severed, so why is it not an icchantika?
Why did the TathÄgata say that it is an icchantika?
World-Honored One!

If one gives rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment because of the Buddha-nature, why did the TathÄgata extensively expound the twelve divisions of the canon for the sake of sentient beings?
World-Honored One!
It is like the four rivers that flow out from Lake Anavatapta.
If there are gods, humans, or the World-Honored Buddhas who say that these rivers do not enter the great ocean but return to their original source, this is impossible.

The mind of enlightenment is also like this. Those who have buddha-nature, whether they hear it or not, whether they keep precepts or not, whether they give or not, whether they cultivate or not, whether they have wisdom or not, will all attain supreme perfect enlightenment.
World-Honored One!
It is like the Yugamdhara mountain, from which the sun rises and reaches the south.
If the sun were to think, I will not go to the west, but return to the east, that would be impossible.

Buddha-nature is also like this. If one does not hear it, does not keep precepts, does not give, does not cultivate, does not have wisdom, and does not attain supreme perfect enlightenment, that is impossible.
World-Honored One!
The buddhas and tathagatas say that the nature of cause and effect is neither existent nor nonexistent. This meaning is also incorrect.
Why is it so?
If milk has no nature of curd, then there is no curd.
The nyagrodha seed does not have the nature of five zhang, and therefore it cannot produce a substance of five zhang.
If the Buddha-nature does not have the tree of anuttara-samyak-sambodhi, how can it produce the tree of anuttara-samyak-sambodhi?
For this reason, the causality you speak of is neither existent nor nonexistent. How does this meaning correspond?
At that time the World-Honored One praised him, saying:
Excellent, excellent!
Good man!
There are two kinds of people in the world who are extremely rare, like the udumbara flower:
One does not commit evil deeds, and the other is able to repent of their faults. Such people are extremely rare.
There are two other kinds of people:
One does good deeds, and the other is grateful.
There are two other kinds of people:
One accepts new teachings, and the other does not forget the old.
There are two other kinds of people:
One creates new things, and the other repairs old things.
There are also two kinds of people:
one who enjoys listening to the Dharma and one who enjoys expounding the Dharma.
There are also two kinds of people:
one who is good at asking questions and one who is good at answering.
The one who is good at asking questions is you.
The one who is good at answering is the TathÄgata.
Good man!

Because of this good question, I am able to turn the unsurpassed Dharma wheel, able to wither the great tree of the twelve links of dependent arising, able to cross the great river of birth and death beyond measure, able to do battle with the demon king PÄpÄ«yÄn, and able to topple the supreme banner established by PÄpÄ«yÄn.
Good man!
As I previously explained, when three kinds of sick people encounter a good doctor, nursing care, and good medicine, or do not encounter them, their illnesses are all cured. What does this mean?
Whether they encounter them or not, it means their lifespans are fixed.
Why is it so?

This person has already cultivated the three kinds of goodness, namely, superior, middling, and inferior, for immeasurable lives. Because of cultivating these three kinds of goodness, he obtains a fixed lifespan.
Like the people of Uttarakuru, whose lifespan is one thousand years.
If there are those who are sick, whether they encounter a good doctor, good medicine, and nursing care, or do not encounter them, they all recover.
Why is this?
Because they have obtained a fixed lifespan.
Good man!
As I have said, if a sick person encounters a good doctor, good medicine, and nursing care, their illness can be cured, but if they do not encounter them, they cannot be cured. What does this mean?
Good man!
Such a person's lifespan is not fixed.
Although their life is not exhausted, there are nine conditions that can shorten their lifespan.
What are the nine?
First, knowing that food is not suitable, yet eating it in reverse;
Second, overeating;
Third, not digesting previous meals, yet eating again;
Fourth, not going to the toilet at the right time;
Fifth, not following the doctor's instructions when sick;
Sixth, not following the instructions of the nurse;
Seventh, forcibly enduring and not vomiting;
Eighth, walking at night, and being struck by evil spirits because of walking at night;
Ninth, excessive sexual activity.
For these reasons, I say that if a sick person encounters medicine, the illness can be cured, but if not, it cannot be cured.
Good man!
What is the meaning of my previous statement that whether they encounter it or not, both cannot be cured?
If a person's life is exhausted, whether they encounter it or not, it cannot be cured.
Why is it so?
Because their life is exhausted.
For this reason, I say that if a sick person encounters medicine or not, they will both not be cured.

Sentient beings are also like this. Those who give rise to the bodhi mind, if they encounter good friends, buddhas, and bodhisattvas, and receive and accept the profound Dharma, even if they do not encounter them, they will all attain [enlightenment].
Why is this?
Because they are able to give rise to the bodhi mind, like the people of Uttarakuru who have a fixed lifespan.

As I have said, from stream-enterers to pratyekabuddhas, if they hear the profound Dharma expounded by good friends, buddhas, and bodhisattvas, they will give rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment. If they do not encounter buddhas, bodhisattvas, or hear the expounding of the profound Dharma, they will not be able to give rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Like those with uncertain lifespans, their lives are cut short due to nine causes.

Like a patient who encounters medicine and is cured of their illness, if they do not encounter it, their illness will not be cured. Therefore, I say that encountering buddhas, bodhisattvas, and hearing the expounding of the profound Dharma, one is then able to give rise to the mind [of enlightenment]. If one does not encounter them, one will not be able to give rise to the mind [of enlightenment].

As I have previously explained, if one encounters good friends, buddhas, bodhisattvas, and hears the profound teachings, or if one does not encounter them, one is still unable to give rise to the mind of enlightenment. What does this mean?
Good man!
If the icchantikas encounter good friends, buddhas, bodhisattvas, and hear the profound teachings, or if they do not encounter them, they are still unable to be free from the icchantika mind.
Why is this?
Because they have cut off good dharmas.
The icchantikas can also attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Why is this?
If one is able to give rise to the mind of enlightenment, then one is no longer called an icchantika.
Good man!
For what reason is it said that the icchantikas can attain supreme, perfect enlightenment?
The icchantikas are truly unable to attain supreme, perfect enlightenment, just as one whose life is exhausted cannot be cured even if they encounter a good doctor, good medicine, and a nurse.
Why is this?
Because their life has ended.
Good man!
E means faith, and chan means not having. Not having faith is called an icchantika.
Buddha-nature is not faith, and sentient beings do not have it. Since they do not have it, how can it be cut off?
E means skillful means, and chan means not having. Not having skillful means for cultivating goodness is called an icchantika.
Buddha-nature is not skillful means for cultivating goodness, and sentient beings do not have it. Since they do not have it, how can it be cut off?
E means vigor, and chan means not having. Not having vigor is called an icchantika.
Buddha-nature is not vigor, and sentient beings do not have it. Since they do not have it, how can it be cut off?
E means mindfulness, and chan means not having. Not having mindfulness is called an icchantika.
Buddha-nature is not mindfulness, and sentient beings do not have it. Since they do not have it, how can it be cut off?
E means definite, and ti means not complete. Because it is definite and not complete, it is called icchantika.
Buddha-nature is not definite, and sentient beings are not complete. Since it is not complete, how can it be cut off?
E means wisdom, and ti means not complete. Because wisdom is not complete, it is called icchantika.
Buddha-nature is not wisdom, and sentient beings are not complete. Since it is not complete, how can it be cut off?
E means impermanent good, and ti means not complete.
Because impermanent good is not complete, it is called icchantika.
Buddha-nature is permanent, neither good nor not good.
Why is it so? Good dharmas must be obtained through skillful means.
But buddha-nature is not obtained through skillful means, therefore it is not good.
Why is it also called not not good?
Because it can obtain the fruit of goodness. The fruit of goodness is precisely supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Moreover, good dharmas are obtained after birth, but buddha-nature is not obtained after birth, and therefore it is not good.
Because one severs the good dharmas obtained after birth, one is called an icchantika.
Good son!
As you say, if an icchantika has buddha-nature, why does it not prevent the sin of hell?
Good son!
Within the icchantika there is no buddha-nature.
Good son!

It is like a king who hears the sound of a lute, and the sound is clear and wonderful, so his mind becomes addicted to it, he delights in it and loves it, and his feelings are never apart from it. He then tells his great minister:
'From where does such a wonderful sound come out?'
The great minister replies:
'Such a wonderful sound comes from the lute.'
The king then says:
'Bring the sound here.'
At that time, the great minister then holds the lute in front of the king and says:
'Great king, you should know that this is the sound.'
The king said to the lute:
'Make a sound, make a sound!'
But the lute still did not make a sound.
Then the great king cut its strings, but the sound still did not come out. He took its skin and wood and split them all apart, searching for the sound but unable to find it.
At that time, the great king became angry with the great minister:
'How can you speak such false words?'
The great minister said to the king:
'As for obtaining a sound, the method is not like this.
It should be with various conditions and skillful means that the sound comes out.'
The Buddha-nature of sentient beings is also like this, having no fixed abode. It can be seen due to skillful means, and because it can be seen, one attains supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Those of the icchantika class do not see the Buddha-nature. How can they block the offenses of the three evil paths?
Good man!
If icchantikas believe in the existence of buddha-nature, know that they will not go to the three evil destinies, and are also not called icchantikas.
Because they do not believe in themselves having buddha-nature, they fall into the three evil destinies. Because they fall into the three evil destinies, they are called icchantikas.
Good son!
As you say, if milk has no nature of curd, it should not produce curd.
If the seed of a banyan tree has no nature of five zhang, it should not have the substance of five zhang.
Foolish people make such statements, but the wise never speak like this.
Why is it so?
Because of the absence of nature.
Good son!
If milk has the nature of curd, it should not depend on the power of various conditions.
Good son!
If water and milk are mixed and left for a month, they still do not become curd.
If a drop of sap from the paku tree is added to it, it immediately becomes curd.
If it originally had curd, why wait for conditions?

The buddha-nature of sentient beings is also like this. It can be seen through the combination of various conditions, and through the combination of various conditions, one can attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.

If it is only after the combination of various conditions that it is accomplished, then it is without intrinsic nature. Because it is without intrinsic nature, one can attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Good man!
For this reason, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas always praise the good in others and do not bring up their shortcomings. This is called the mind of straightforwardness.

What is the mind of straightforwardness of bodhisattvas?

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas never commit evil. If they make a mistake, they immediately repent. They never conceal their faults from their teachers and fellow students. They feel ashamed and reproach themselves, not daring to do it again. They regard even minor offenses as extremely serious.
If someone questions them, they answer, I have indeed committed an offense.
They are further asked, Is this offense good or bad?
They answer, It is not good.
They are further asked, Is this offense wholesome or unwholesome?
He replied, Unwholesome.
He further asked, Is this crime a good result or an unwholesome result?
He replied, This crime is indeed not a good result.

Because of his sincere mind, he believes in the Buddha-nature. Because he believes in the Buddha-nature, he cannot be called an icchantika.

Because of his sincere mind, he is called a disciple of the Buddha. If he receives from sentient beings robes, food and drink, bedding, and medicine, each worth a thousand, it is not considered much. This is called a bodhisattva's sincere mind.
How does a bodhisattva cultivate and practice the precepts?

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas uphold the precepts, not for rebirth in the heavens or out of fear, and do not even accept the precepts of dogs, chickens, cows, or pheasants. Although there are Shariputra, Maudgalyayana, and others, they are not called true good and virtuous friends of sentient beings.

Because you taught them wrongly, you caused these two to give rise to evil thoughts.

If there are good sons and good women who, for the sake of the great parinirvÄá¹‡a, are endowed with and accomplish these five things, they can do what is difficult to do, endure what is difficult to endure, and give what is difficult to give.

If they hear that by experiencing suffering, being struck with fists, sticks, knives, and stones, one can attain great parinirvÄá¹‡a, they will for immeasurable asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas physically endure it all without considering it suffering. If they hear that by giving away their country, city, wife, children, head, eyes, marrow, and brain to others, one can attain supreme, perfect enlightenment, they will give away all their possessions, including their country, city, wife, children, head, eyes, marrow, and brain to others for immeasurable and incalculable eons. Although the bodhisattva may do what is difficult to do, he never thinks, This is what I have done;
difficult giving is also like this.

It is like a parent who has only one child, cherishing it deeply, providing it with fine clothing and delicious food, nurturing it according to the seasons, and ensuring that it lacks nothing.
If the child gives rise to a mind of contempt towards its parents, speaking evil words and insulting them,
the parents, out of love, do not become angry or resentful, nor do they think, We provide this child with clothing and food.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are also like this. They regard all sentient beings as their only child. If the child encounters illness, the parents also become ill. They diligently seek medicine and treat the child. Even after the child's illness is cured, they never think, I treated the child's illness and suffering.

Bodhisattvas are also like this. Seeing that sentient beings encounter the illness of afflictions, they give rise to a mind of loving-kindness and expound the Dharma for them. Because of hearing the Dharma, the afflictions are severed. After the afflictions are severed, they never think, I have severed the afflictions for sentient beings.
If they give rise to this thought, they will never be able to accomplish supreme perfect enlightenment.
They only think like this: There is not a single sentient being for whom I expound the Dharma to sever afflictions.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas do not become angry or joyful towards sentient beings.
Why is this?
Because they are well able to cultivate the samÄdhi of emptiness.
If bodhisattvas cultivate the samÄdhi of emptiness, then towards whom should they give rise to anger or joy?
Good man!
It is like a mountain forest being burned by a raging fire, if a person cuts it down or carries it away by water, would the forest give rise to anger or joy towards anyone?
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are also like this, having no anger or joy towards any sentient beings.
Why is it so?
Because they cultivate the samÄdhi of emptiness.
At that time, the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva Supreme Virtuous King of Universal Illumination addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
Are all dharmas by nature empty?
Because emptiness is empty.
If the nature is originally empty, one should not cultivate emptiness and then see emptiness.
How can the TathÄgata say that one sees emptiness by cultivating emptiness?
If the nature is originally not empty, even if one cultivates emptiness, one cannot make it empty.
Good man!
The nature of all dharmas is originally empty.
Why is it so?
Because the nature of all dharmas cannot be obtained.
Good man!
The nature of form cannot be apprehended.
What is the nature of form?

The nature of form is not earth, water, fire, or wind, yet it is not separate from earth, water, fire, and wind. It is not blue, yellow, red, or white, yet it is not separate from blue, yellow, red, and white. It is neither existent nor nonexistent. How can it be said that form has its own nature?
Because its nature cannot be apprehended, it is said to be empty.
All dharmas are also like this. Because of similarity and continuity, ordinary beings, upon seeing, say that the nature of dharmas is not empty and tranquil.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are endowed with five things, and therefore see the nature of dharmas as originally empty and tranquil.
Good man!
